item.title: Alex Bala’s Fried Mac n Cheese Balls
item.description: Golden, crispy and filled with gooey, cheesy goodness, these crispy fried Parmesan mac n cheese balls are comfort food in bite-sized form. They’re perfect for parties, game day, or turning leftover mac and cheese into something totally irresistible. Each ball has a crunchy panko coating, a melty center, and just the right hint of garlic and Parmesan. Dip them in Buffalo sauce for the ultimate flavor combo! —Alex Bala, Longmont, Colorado

item.description: If you’re missing mango sticky rice season, give this recipe a try instead! item.title: THE STORY OF IRISH LAMB: FROM HILL FARMS TO THE SUNDAY ROAST
item.description:
Among Ireland’s most treasured foods, few ingredients tell a story as rich and enduring as Irish lamb. From the windswept hills of Connemara to the green pastures of Wicklow, sheep have grazed across this landscape for centuries, shaping not only the countryside but the culture itself. Their wool clothed generations, their milk sustained families, and their meat became a centerpiece of celebration—from humble farm kitchens to Sunday roasts shared around the family table. Irish lamb is more than a dish; it’s a reflection of Ireland’s land, history, and people. Each region produces meat with its own distinct character, born from the herbs, grasses, and sea breezes that flavor the pastures. Whether slow-roasted, stewed with root vegetables, or grilled over open flame, lamb connects modern Ireland to a pastoral tradition that stretches back thousands of years. Table of Contents 1. Introduction: Ireland’s Gift from the Hills 2. The Origins of Irish Sheep Farming 3. Life on the Hill Farms 4. Lamb in Irish History and Culture 5. The Modern Irish Lamb Industry and the Sunday Roast Introduction: Ireland’s Gift from the Hills In Ireland, the story of lamb begins in the hills. Sheep have roamed this land since ancient times, thriving on wild grasses and heather-covered slopes where few other animals could. The rugged landscape shaped a breed of animals as hardy as the people who tended them. Generations of farmers perfected the art of raising lambs naturally, allowing the rhythm of the seasons to guide every part of the process. Today, Irish lamb continues to embody that connection between land and livelihood. Its unique flavor—mild yet rich, earthy yet sweet—comes directly from the natural environment. It’s a product of open pastures, fresh air, and a way of life that values stewardship as much as sustenance. From the remote farms of Kerry to the Sunday dinners of Dublin, lamb remains Ireland’s gift from the hills. The Origins of Irish Sheep Farming The history of sheep farming in Ireland stretches back thousands of years. Archaeological evidence suggests that sheep were first brought to Ireland around 4000 BCE by early Neolithic settlers, who valued them for their milk, wool, and meat. Over time, sheep became an integral part of rural life, adapting perfectly to the island’s temperate climate and hilly terrain. In ancient Celtic society, sheep were symbols of wealth and fertility, and their presence was woven into myths, trade, and seasonal festivals. Wool became a key resource, providing warmth and clothing long before industrial weaving emerged. Sheep were not only valuable for their fleece but also as a sustainable source of food—especially in the form of mutton, which sustained rural communities through the colder months. By the early Christian period, Irish monasteries were at the forefront of organized sheep farming. Monks raised flocks to supply wool for clothing, parchment for writing, and meat for fasting days when beef or pork was forbidden. The integration of sheep into both the spiritual and economic life of Ireland helped solidify their importance for centuries to come. Throughout the medieval era, sheep farming expanded across the island. Different breeds emerged in response to local geography—from hardy mountain sheep in the west to softer-fleeced lowland varieties in the east. This regional diversity would later shape the flavors and qualities of Irish lamb, creating the foundation for the distinctive taste we know today. By the time Ireland’s farming landscape began to modernize, sheep were already part of its natural and cultural fabric. The relationship between people, land, and livestock had become a defining feature of Irish rural identity—a legacy that endures on hill farms to this day. Life on the Hill Farms Across Ireland’s rugged western and southern counties—places like Connemara, Kerry, and Donegal—hill farming has shaped both the landscape and the lives of those who work it. These remote upland regions, marked by rocky ground, thin soil, and unpredictable weather, are ideal for sheep but little else. Here, lambs graze freely on wild herbs, grasses, and heather, developing the rich, distinctive flavor that defines Irish hill lamb. For centuries, families in these areas have followed the same seasonal rhythm: lambing in spring, grazing through the summer, and bringing animals down from the hills before the winter storms. Many of these farms are small and family-run, passed down through generations. The work is demanding—early mornings, long days, and constant care for the flock—but it’s also deeply tied to tradition and pride. Hill farmers rely on their intimate knowledge of the land. They know which slopes catch the first sun, where shelter can be found from Atlantic winds, and how to manage flocks in terrain that would challenge machinery. The connection between farmer and landscape is personal, almost sacred—a continuation of a way of life that dates back thousands of years. The result of this care and environment is lamb with a flavor impossible to replicate elsewhere. The diet of wild plants gives the meat a subtle sweetness and depth that chefs and consumers around the world admire. In many ways, Irish hill lamb is a taste of the land itself—pure, natural, and shaped by the wind and rain that define the Irish countryside. Even as modern farming methods spread, the traditional hill farms remain a cornerstone of Irish agriculture. They preserve biodiversity, protect rural culture, and continue to produce some of the finest lamb in Europe—each animal a testament to Ireland’s enduring bond between land and livelihood. Lamb in Irish History and Culture Lamb has held a special place in Irish history and culture for centuries—both as a daily sustenance and a symbol of faith, renewal, and hospitality. In the ancient world, sheep were prized for their versatility, providing wool for clothing, milk for cheese and butter, and meat for feasting. Over time, lamb became not just a practical food but a meaningful one, woven into Ireland’s seasonal rhythms and social life. In medieval Ireland, mutton—meat from older sheep—was more common than tender lamb, as flocks were raised primarily for wool. However, lamb took on a ceremonial

The work is demanding—early mornings, long days, and constant care for the flock—but it’s also deeply tied to tradition and pride. Hill farmers rely on their intimate knowledge of the land. They know which slopes catch the first sun, where shelter can be found from Atlantic winds, and how to manage flocks in terrain that would challenge machinery. The connection between farmer and landscape is personal, almost sacred—a continuation of a way of life that dates back thousands of years. The result of this care and environment is lamb with a flavor impossible to replicate elsewhere. The diet of wild plants gives the meat a subtle sweetness and depth that chefs and consumers around the world admire. In many ways, Irish hill lamb is a taste of the land itself—pure, natural, and shaped by the wind and rain that define the Irish countryside. Even as modern farming methods spread, the traditional hill farms remain a cornerstone of Irish agriculture. They preserve biodiversity, protect rural culture, and continue to produce some of the finest lamb in Europe—each animal a testament to Ireland’s enduring bond between land and livelihood. Lamb in Irish History and Culture Lamb has held a special place in Irish history and culture for centuries—both as a daily sustenance and a symbol of faith, renewal, and hospitality. In the ancient world, sheep were prized for their versatility, providing wool for clothing, milk for cheese and butter, and meat for feasting. Over time, lamb became not just a practical food but a meaningful one, woven into Ireland’s seasonal rhythms and social life. In medieval Ireland, mutton—meat from older sheep—was more common than tender lamb, as flocks were raised primarily for wool. However, lamb took on a ceremonial
The post [THE STORY OF IRISH LAMB: FROM HILL FARMS TO THE SUNDAY ROAST](https://irishfoodhub.com/irish-lamb-tradition-3/) appeared first on [Irish Food Hub](https://irishfoodhub.com).

item.title: PARSNIP AND HAZELNUT PURÉE
item.description:
Parsnip & Hazelnut Purée – An Elegant Irish Side for Roasts Description: Creamy, nutty, and perfectly smooth — this Parsnip & Hazelnut Purée is a refined take on a classic Irish side. The sweetness of roasted parsnips meets the toasted richness of hazelnuts, creating a luxurious accompaniment to roast meats, poultry, or festive vegetarian dishes. Preparation Time: 10 minutes Cooking Time: 25 minutes Serving Size: Serves 4 Ingredients 500g (1 lb) parsnips, peeled and chopped 50g (½ cup) hazelnuts, toasted 1 tbsp butter 100ml (⅓ cup) cream or milk 1 tbsp olive oil Salt and freshly ground black pepper Optional garnish: chopped toasted hazelnuts or fresh herbs Instructions Step 1 – Cook the Parsnips Place the chopped parsnips in a saucepan, cover with salted water, and simmer for 15–20 minutes until tender. Drain well. Step 2 – Toast the Hazelnuts While the parsnips cook, toast the hazelnuts in a dry pan for 3–4 minutes until fragrant. Remove skins by rubbing them in a clean towel, then roughly chop. Step 3 – Blend the Purée Place the parsnips, hazelnuts, butter, cream, and olive oil in a blender or food processor. Blend until smooth, adding a little extra cream if needed for desired consistency. Step 4 – Season and Serve Season with salt and pepper to taste. Spoon onto a serving dish and top with chopped hazelnuts or herbs for garnish. Serving Suggestion Serve alongside roast beef, pork, or turkey — or as a sophisticated vegetarian side dish that adds texture and warmth to any Irish table.

The post PARSNIP AND HAZELNUT PURÉE appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: SEAWEED AND POTATO SALAD
item.description:
Seaweed & Potato Salad – A Fresh Nod to Coastal Irish Cooking Description: Inspired by Ireland’s rugged coastline, this Seaweed & Potato Salad blends tender baby potatoes with delicate seaweed for a dish that’s both earthy and oceanic. Lightly dressed with lemon and olive oil, it’s a refreshing taste of Irish coastal tradition. Preparation Time: 15 minutes Cooking Time: 15 minutes Serving Size: Serves 4 Ingredients 600g (1¼ lb) baby potatoes 15g (½ oz) dried seaweed (dulse or sea lettuce), soaked and chopped 2 tbsp olive oil 1 tbsp lemon juice 1 tsp Dijon mustard 2 spring onions, finely sliced 2 tbsp chopped parsley or dill Salt and freshly ground black pepper Optional: 1 tbsp mayonnaise or Greek yogurt for creaminess Instructions Step 1 – Cook the Potatoes Boil the baby potatoes in salted water for 10–12 minutes until tender. Drain and allow to cool slightly before halving or slicing. Step 2 – Prepare the Seaweed If using dried seaweed, soak in warm water for 10 minutes to rehydrate, then rinse and chop finely. Step 3 – Make the Dressing Whisk together olive oil, lemon juice, mustard, and a little salt and pepper until emulsified. Stir in the herbs and spring onions. Step 4 – Combine and Serve Toss the warm potatoes with the dressing and seaweed until evenly coated. Adjust seasoning to taste. Serve warm or chilled. Serving Suggestion This salad pairs beautifully with grilled fish or smoked salmon and makes a flavorful addition to any Irish-style seafood spread.

The post SEAWEED AND POTATO SALAD appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: Hetal Vasavada’s Pumpkin Slab Pie with Cranberry Jam Swirl
item.description: This pumpkin slab pie with cranberry jam swirl takes the best parts of the Thanksgiving dessert with pumpkin, spice and a buttery crust and gives them a festive twist. The tangy cranberry jam is swirled into the silky pumpkin filling, adding bright bursts of color and flavor to every slice. It’s tart meets cozy, a little sweet, a little sharp and perfect for feeding a crowd without a lot of ingredients! —Hetal Vasavada, San Francisco, California

item.description: If you’re looking for an easy show-stopping appetizer that feels elegant but comes together in minutes, these prosciutto pear cups are the perfect bite-sized indulgence. Crispy, salty prosciutto forms the base for creamy Brie and a bright pear-arugula salad that’s lightly dressed with olive oil, thyme and a drizzle of balsamic. The result is a beautiful balance of sweet, savory and tangy flavors. —Elise Jesse, Cincinnati, Ohio

item.title: IRISH BARLEY: THE ANCIENT GRAIN STILL FEEDING THE NATION
item.description:
Long before the potato arrived in Ireland, there was barley — a humble grain that sustained the island’s people for millennia. From the earliest farmers who sowed it in stony soil to the monks who brewed ale within cloistered walls, barley has been intertwined with Ireland’s story from the beginning. It was one of the first crops ever cultivated here and remains a cornerstone of Irish life, both in the kitchen and the pint glass. Resilient, versatile, and deeply rooted in the land, barley has fed Ireland through famine, faith, and feast. It appears in everything from soups and breads to the whiskey and beer that have carried Ireland’s name around the world. Despite centuries of change, this ancient grain still holds a vital place in Irish fields and Irish hearts. Table of Contents The Grain That Built a Nation Ancient Origins of Barley in Ireland Barley in Monastic and Medieval Life The Brewing and Whiskey Connection Barley’s Revival in Modern Ireland The Grain That Built a Nation Barley has been part of Ireland’s landscape for more than 5,000 years. Its golden fields stretch across the country each summer, a living link to the island’s earliest farmers. Easy to grow and rich in nutrition, barley sustained generations through times of plenty and hardship alike. For centuries, it was the grain that built daily bread, fortified broths, and filled tankards with ale. In a country known for rain and resilience, barley’s hardiness made it indispensable. It thrived where other crops struggled and formed the foundation of a food system that was as practical as it was spiritual. Whether in a bowl of warming soup, a monk’s fasting bread, or a brewer’s malted mash, barley has remained Ireland’s most enduring crop — the quiet heart of its agricultural heritage. Ancient Origins of Barley in Ireland Barley is among the oldest cultivated grains in human history — and in Ireland, it predates recorded civilization. Archaeological evidence shows that early farmers were growing and harvesting barley as far back as 4000 BCE, during the Neolithic period. It was one of the first crops to take root in Ireland’s cool, damp climate, thriving where wheat often failed. Excavations at ancient sites such as Newgrange and Ceide Fields have revealed barley grains and impressions of cereal stalks preserved in the soil. These discoveries tell the story of a people who transitioned from foraging to farming, relying on hardy crops that could sustain them year-round. Barley became not just a source of food, but a foundation for settled life. Early Irish communities used barley in multiple ways: ground into meal for bread, boiled into gruel or stirabout, and fermented into a primitive form of ale. Its versatility made it an essential part of both everyday sustenance and early ritual feasting. In fact, barley was so central that it appears in Irish mythology — linked with fertility, abundance, and the cycles of the land. As the centuries passed, barley’s importance only deepened. It became a key trade good, a form of rent or tribute, and a symbol of prosperity. In many ways, barley was to early Ireland what the potato would later become — the grain that quietly fed the nation. Barley in Monastic and Medieval Life As Christianity spread across Ireland in the early centuries AD, barley became a cornerstone of monastic self-sufficiency. The monks who built Ireland’s early monasteries—places like Clonmacnoise, Glendalough, and Skellig Michael—cultivated barley in the fertile lands surrounding their communities. It was a grain of both nourishment and devotion, woven into the rhythm of daily life. Barley bread was a staple food in these monastic settlements. While fine wheaten loaves were reserved for feast days, barley bread was the daily fare of monks and laborers alike. It was hearty, coarse, and sustaining—perfect for those living under the strict fasting rules of the monastic calendar. Combined with vegetables, herbs, and dairy, it formed the basis of a simple but balanced diet. Barley also played a key role in monastic brewing. Many Irish monasteries maintained small breweries, producing ale that was safer to drink than water and vital during fasting periods when solid food was limited. The brewing process itself was seen as a craft of discipline and order, mirroring the monks’ devotion to prayer and labor. In this way, barley became part of both physical and spiritual sustenance. Outside the monasteries, barley flourished in medieval Ireland as a peasant crop. It grew well in poorer soils and required less maintenance than wheat, making it ideal for small farms and tenant plots. Barley bread and porridge were everyday foods for rural families, while malted barley continued to fuel both domestic brewing and the growing trade in ale and beer. By the end of the medieval period, barley had become inseparable from Ireland’s identity—feeding monks, farmers, and merchants alike, and linking the sacred and the ordinary in a single, golden grain. The Brewing and Whiskey Connection Few crops are as deeply tied to Ireland’s cultural identity as barley, and nowhere is that connection more evident than in the nation’s brewing and distilling traditions. For over a thousand years, Irish barley has provided the backbone of both ale and whiskey—two beverages that have nourished, inspired, and defined Irish life at home and abroad. Long before commercial breweries existed, Irish monks were among the first to refine the art of brewing. Using malted barley, they crafted ales for sustenance, hospitality, and even medicinal purposes. Brewing was a daily part of monastic life, and recipes varied by region and available ingredients. These early barley-based ales were the ancestors of Ireland’s modern brewing heritage. By the 18th century, barley had become central to another iconic craft—Irish whiskey. Distillers discovered that malted and unmalted barley together produced a distinctive, smooth spirit that became the hallmark of Irish whiskey. From small rural stills to great names like Jameson, Powers, and Bushmills, the tradition of turning barley into liquid gold spread across the island. Barley’s dual role in both brewing and distilling

Long before the potato arrived in Ireland, there was barley — a humble grain that sustained the island’s people for millennia. From the earliest farmers who sowed it in stony soil to the monks who brewed ale within cloistered walls, barley has been intertwined with Ireland’s story from the beginning. It was one of the first crops ever cultivated here and remains a cornerstone of Irish life, both in the kitchen and the pint glass. Resilient, versatile, and deeply rooted in the land, barley has fed Ireland through famine, faith, and feast. It appears in everything from soups and breads to the whiskey and beer that have carried Ireland’s name around the world. Despite centuries of change, this ancient grain still holds a vital place in Irish fields and Irish hearts. Its golden fields stretch across the country each summer, a living link to the island’s earliest farmers. Easy to grow and rich in nutrition, barley sustained generations through times of plenty and hardship alike. For centuries, it was the grain that built daily bread, fortified broths, and filled tankards with ale. In a country known for rain and resilience, barley’s hardiness made it indispensable. It thrived where other crops struggled and formed the foundation of a food system that was as practical as it was spiritual. Whether in a bowl of warming soup, a monk’s fasting bread, or a brewer’s malted mash, barley has remained Ireland’s most enduring crop — the quiet heart of its agricultural heritage. Archaeological evidence shows that early farmers were growing and harvesting barley as far back as 4000 BCE, during the Neolithic period. It was one of the first crops to take root in Ireland’s cool, damp climate, thriving where wheat often failed. Excavations at ancient sites such as Newgrange and Ceide Fields have revealed barley grains and impressions of cereal stalks preserved in the soil. These discoveries tell the story of a people who transitioned from foraging to farming, relying on hardy crops that could sustain them year-round. Barley became not just a source of food, but a foundation for settled life. Early Irish communities used barley in multiple ways: ground into meal for bread, boiled into gruel or stirabout, and fermented into a primitive form of ale. Its versatility made it an essential part of both everyday sustenance and early ritual feasting. item.title: WILD GARLIC AND POTATO SOUP
item.description:
Wild Garlic & Potato Soup – A Seasonal and Fragrant Irish Spring Dish Description: Celebrate springtime in Ireland with this beautifully fragrant Wild Garlic & Potato Soup. Made with tender new potatoes and freshly foraged wild garlic leaves, it’s creamy, comforting, and naturally vibrant — the essence of the Irish countryside in a bowl. Preparation Time: 10 minutes Cooking Time: 25 minutes Serving Size: Serves 4 Ingredients 1 tbsp butter or olive oil 1 medium onion, chopped 2 cloves garlic, minced 300g (10 oz) potatoes, peeled and diced 750ml (3 cups) vegetable stock 100g (3.5 oz) wild garlic leaves, washed and roughly chopped 100ml (½ cup) cream or milk Salt and freshly ground black pepper Fresh herbs or wild garlic flowers, for garnish Instructions Step 1 – Sauté the Aromatics In a large pot, melt butter over medium heat. Add the onion and garlic, cooking gently until softened but not browned. Step 2 – Add the Potatoes and Stock Stir in the diced potatoes and pour in the vegetable stock. Bring to a simmer and cook for 15–20 minutes until the potatoes are tender. Step 3 – Add the Wild Garlic Add the wild garlic leaves and cook for another 2–3 minutes, just until wilted. Remove from heat. Step 4 – Blend and Finish Blend the soup until smooth using a hand blender. Stir in the cream or milk, season to taste, and warm through gently before serving. Step 5 – Serve Pour into bowls and garnish with a drizzle of cream and a few wild garlic flowers or herbs for a fresh finish. Serving Suggestion Serve with brown soda bread or oatcakes for a wholesome Irish lunch that celebrates spring’s bounty.

The post WILD GARLIC AND POTATO SOUP appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: BEETROOT AND CASHEL BLUE SOUP
item.description:
Beetroot & Cashel Blue Soup – Vibrant and Tangy Irish Comfort Description: This stunning beetroot soup pairs earthy Irish beetroot with the creamy tang of Cashel Blue cheese. Its vibrant magenta color and bold flavor make it both elegant and comforting — a perfect starter for a cozy meal or festive dinner. Preparation Time: 15 minutes Cooking Time: 30 minutes Serving Size: Serves 4 Ingredients 500g (1 lb) cooked beetroot, chopped 1 medium onion, chopped 1 tbsp butter or olive oil 750ml (3 cups) vegetable stock 100ml (⅓ cup) cream 75g (2.5 oz) Cashel Blue cheese, crumbled (plus extra for garnish) 1 small potato, peeled and diced Salt and freshly ground black pepper Fresh chives or parsley, for garnish Instructions Step 1 – Sauté the Vegetables In a large saucepan, melt the butter over medium heat. Add onion and potato, cooking gently for 5 minutes until softened. Step 2 – Add Beetroot and Stock Stir in the chopped beetroot and pour in the vegetable stock. Bring to a simmer and cook for 15–20 minutes until all vegetables are tender. Step 3 – Blend and Enrich Remove from heat. Use a hand blender or food processor to blend until smooth. Stir in cream and most of the Cashel Blue cheese until melted and combined. Step 4 – Season and Serve Season with salt and pepper to taste. Ladle into bowls and garnish with crumbled blue cheese, chopped chives, and a drizzle of cream. Serving Suggestion Serve with crusty brown soda bread for a hearty and beautifully colored Irish-inspired meal.

The post BEETROOT AND CASHEL BLUE SOUP appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: Tam To’s Apple Pie Sticky Rice
item.description: This apple pie sticky rice is a cozy autumn twist on the delicious Thai dessert, mango sticky rice. When mango season ends and apple season begins, this recipe keeps the comfort going. The soft apple filling mimics the sweetness and texture of ripe mangoes. Served with a cinnamon-infused coconut milk sauce, it’s a dessert that brings together summer vibes and fall coziness in one bowl. —Tam To, Los Angeles, California
item.source:markdown: This apple pie sticky rice is a cozy autumn twist on the delicious Thai dessert, mango sticky rice. item.title: Elise Jesse’s Pumpkin Gruyere Pasta
item.description: There’s a new side for Thanksgiving this year: creamy, comforting pumpkin Gruyere pasta. It's fancy enough for a holiday but easy enough for a weeknight dinner that won’t break the budget. Velvety pumpkin puree blends with nutty Gruyere cheese to create a luscious sauce that clings to every noodle, while fried sage leaves add a fragrant, crispy finish. It’s my favorite way to introduce something new and delicious to my holiday table. —Elise Jesse, Cincinnati, Ohio

item.title: IRISH-STYLE CRANACHAN
item.description:
Cranachan Irish-Style – A Whiskey and Cream Twist on a Scottish Classic Description: Cranachan, a traditional Scottish dessert of cream, oats, honey, and raspberries, takes on a distinctly Irish character in this version. By swapping in Irish cream liqueur and a splash of whiskey, this indulgent treat becomes a silky, boozy delight that’s perfect for celebrations. Preparation Time: 20 minutesChilling Time: 30 minutesServing Size: Serves 4 Ingredients 75g (¾ cup) rolled oats 300ml (1 ¼ cups) double cream 3 tbsp Irish cream liqueur 2 tbsp Irish whiskey 3 tbsp clear honey (preferably Irish) 200g (7 oz) fresh raspberries Extra honey and raspberries, for garnish Instructions Step 1 – Toast the Oats In a dry frying pan, toast the oats over medium heat until golden and fragrant, about 5 minutes. Set aside to cool. Step 2 – Whip the Cream In a large bowl, whip the cream until it forms soft peaks. Gently fold in the Irish cream liqueur, whiskey, and honey. Step 3 – Assemble the Dessert In serving glasses, layer raspberries, cream mixture, and toasted oats. Repeat until the glasses are filled, finishing with a swirl of cream on top. Step 4 – Chill and Serve Chill for 30 minutes before serving. Garnish with extra raspberries and a drizzle of honey. Serving Suggestion For an extra indulgence, serve with a splash more whiskey on the side or a drizzle of chocolate over the top.

The post IRISH-STYLE CRANACHAN appeared first on Irish Food Hub.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Tam To’s Korean Spicy Braised Chicken
item.description: This Korean spicy braised chicken is a healthier, flavor-packed alternative to fried chicken. Made in just one pot, this protein-rich meal comes together in under 40 minutes. —Tam To, Los Angeles, California
